channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Delhi’s Indo-Western Style
item.description: A young Indian finds fashion inspiration in a national hero in New Delhi’s artsy Hauz Khas Village neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Newly Detected Objects Draw Searchers for Malaysian Plane
item.description: The Australian prime minister said on Thursday that satellite imagery had detected objects in the southern Indian Ocean that might be connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Australian Maritime Safety Authority, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A handout picture made available on Thursday by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority shows a map of the search area for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Year Later, Dead Pigs Discovered in Another Chinese River
item.description: On Wednesday, officials in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, said that more than 100 dead pigs had been pulled from the Gan River.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A photograph taken on Tuesday showing a dead pig pulled from the Gan River in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Assault on Hong Kong Media Executives Adds to Press Freedom Concerns
item.description: An attack on two executives of a Hong Kong newspaper by men with iron bars is the second such high-profile assault in less than a month.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A protester held a sign calling for the protection of press freedom during a demonstration in Hong Kong in support of Kevin Lau, the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper who was stabbed by two knife-wielding assailants.

item.title: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
item.description: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Second Round of Iran Nuclear Talks Ends With Optimism
item.description: Both sides described the negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program as “useful and substantive,” and talks will resume in April.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Relatives of Ghanaian Who Died During Deportation Win Ruling in Japan
item.description: A Tokyo court ordered the Justice Ministry to pay about $50,000 to the family of the man, who had suffocated in a plane seat under excessive force.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Many Seek Spanish Citizenship Offered to Sephardic Jews
item.description: After approving legislation that it will grand dual citizenship to descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled from the country, the Spanish government has received thousands of inquiries.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: DealBook: In Hong Kong, Betting Big on Bitcoin
item.description: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has created an opening for Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Shin, a Hong Kong investment banker, is building a stock exchange for Bitcoin-oriented companies.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Corruption Probe’s Details Will Not Be Disclosed
item.description: Parliament voted on Wednesday against the public disclosure of accusations against four former government ministers who have been implicated in a major corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Paying Price, 16 Years Later, for an Illegal Entry
item.description: A man’s case previews the difficulties President Obama will face in a review he ordered last week, asking the Homeland Security secretary to come up with a more “humane” deportation policy.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON and DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Steve Hebert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs of Josue Noe Sandoval-Perez and his children on the refrigerator of their home. Mr. Sandoval-Perez, 41, in the country illegally for 16 years, was deported to Mexico in January.

item.title: Tempered Cheers in Ukraine for Ex-Premier, Tied to Political Past
item.description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, recently released from prison, has emerged as a pivotal, if not beloved, figure in a nation that finds itself directly astride the East-West divide.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister, in Kiev this month. She is expected to run for president.

item.title: NATO Weighs Assistance for Ukraine to Dissuade Further Moves by Moscow
item.description: The secretary general of the alliance said that Ukraine had requested the aid, and that a decision on what to provide would be made at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in April.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: After East Harlem Explosion, Mourning a Japanese Daughter Who Loved New York
item.description: The mother and brother of Mayumi Nakamura, 34, who was killed in a gas explosion last week, prepared to carry her ashes back to Japan.
item.dc:creator: By WINNIE HU

item.title: At Trial, Son-in-Law Recalls a Cave Meeting With Bin Laden on 9/11
item.description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, Osama Bin Laden’s most senior adviser to be tried in a civilian court, said the former Qaeda leader summoned him on the night of the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, left, with Osama bin Laden, in a video from after the Sept. 11 attacks.

item.title: Editorial Observer: Revisiting Gandhi, on the Banks of the Sabarmati
item.description: An old ashram is a place to reflect on a new India of skyrocketing growth.
item.dc:creator: By MIRA KAMDAR

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Ex-Editor Says He Was Told to Take Blame for Phone Hacking
item.description: Clive Goodman, the former royal editor at the now-defunct News of the World, told a London court on Wednesday that senior officials of News International, pressured him to avoid implicating others.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Rebels Seize Southern Prison
item.description: Rebels took over a prison in Daraa Province on Wednesday, expanding their control near the border with Jordan and freeing hundreds of prisoners, antigovernment activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing: Kenya: Two Charged With Terrorism-Related Offenses
item.description: A court in Mombasa charged two suspects suspected of being Somali Islamist militants after they were arrested driving a car carrying pipe bombs and grenades.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Plane Debris Would Be Modest Clue Two Weeks After a Crash, Experts Say
item.description: If searchers spotted floating debris from the missing Malaysia Airlines jet in the ocean, it would be more dispersed and farther from the wreckage sunk beneath the waves, experts said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: U.N. Stymied in Efforts to Take Aid to Syrians
item.description: Despite a Security Council resolution ordering the unhindered flow of food and medicine into Syria, aid workers are struggling even to get across the border.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Pakistan Vows to Improve Journalists’ Freedom and Safety
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said his government would investigate targeted violence, ease visa and travel limits, and review the expulsion of a reporter for The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS SCHORZMAN

item.title: The Lede: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
item.description: Posts on the Facebook and YouTube accounts maintained by Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah support descriptions of him by friends as a man without extremist leanings in religion or politics.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How to Punish Putin
item.description: If the West is serious about Ukraine, it must stop enabling Russia’s corrupt oligarchs.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXEY A. NAVALNY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: After the Protests
item.description: Social media is fueling a boom-and-bust cycle of political activism.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ZEYNEP TUFEKCI
